required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Group Cognitive Behavioural Therapy on Comorbid Insomnia and Depression in Youth
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Group Cognitive Behavioural Therapy on Comorbid Insomnia and Depression in Youth: a Randomised, Assessor Blind, Parallel Group Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is among the most common psychiatric disorders among adolescents, and is associated with considerable psychosocial and functional impairments and an elevated risk of suicidal behaviour and completed suicide. Meanwhile, sleep disturbance, particularly insomnia, is among the most prevalent and prominent presenting complaints in adolescents with depression. Despite its high prevalence, insomnia often remains overlooked and under-treated in clinical practice. However, growing evidence suggests an intricate relationship between insomnia and depression, which has become an area in need of further focused attention. This project will involve a randomised controlled trial proposed to examine whether insomnia treatment confers additional benefit to depression treatment in adolescents with comorbid depression and insomnia, for improving sleep and depressive symptoms, and other clinical and daytime symptoms as well as overall functional improvement in both the short and long term. Eligible adolescent participants will be randomised to either intervention (8-week group Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Insomnia, CBT-I, or 8-week group Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Depression, CBT-D) or waiting-list control condition. Assessments will be conducted at pre-treatment (week 0), during the treatment (week 2, 4, 6) and post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of the last group session). The two active treatment groups will be additionally followed up at posttreatment one-month and six-month.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
primary_outcome.description: Children's Depression Rating Scale (CDRS-R) is a 17-item rating scale based on a semistructured interview with children. Possible scores range from 17 to 113, with higher scores indicating severer depressive symptoms.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
primary_outcome.description: Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) is a self-assessed scale for detecting states of depression and anxiety. The depression subscale range in scores from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating severer states of depression. Similarly, the anxiety subscale range in scores from 0-21 with higher scores indicating severer states of anxiety. No additional computation will be made with the two subscores.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
primary_outcome.description: Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) is a 5-item self-rated scale. Possible scores range from 0 to 20, with higher scores indicating higher insomnia severity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep quality
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) is a self-rated scale consisting of 19 questions. All items are combined to form seven component scores on different aspects of sleep quality, each of which ranges from 0 to 3 points with higher scores representing more sleep disturbance. The seven component scores are added to one global score, which ranges from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating more difficulties with sleep.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep diary measure (time in bed, TIB)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Daily sleep diary for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by daily sleep diary: time in bed (TIB) in hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep diary measure (total sleep time, TST)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Daily sleep diary for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by daily sleep diary: total sleep time (TST) in hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep diary measure (sleep onset latency, SOL)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Daily sleep diary for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by daily sleep diary: sleep onset latency (SOL) in mins

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep diary measure (wake after sleep onset, WASO)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Daily sleep diary for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by daily sleep diary: wake after sleep onset (WASO) in mins

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep diary measure (sleep efficiency, SE)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Daily sleep diary for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by daily sleep diary: sleep efficiency (SE), which is calculated by total sleep time divided by total time in bed, %

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective sleep measure (time in bed, TIB)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Actigraphic assessment for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by wrist actigraphy: time in bed (TIB) in hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective sleep measure (total sleep time, TST)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Actigraphic assessment for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by wrist actigraphy: total sleep time (TST) in hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective sleep measure (sleep onset latency, SOL)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Actigraphic assessment for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by wrist actigraphy: sleep onset latency (SOL) in mins

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective sleep measure (wake after sleep onset, WASO)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Actigraphic assessment for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by wrist actigraphy: wake after sleep onset (WASO) in mins

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective sleep measure (sleep efficiency, SE)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Actigraphic assessment for consecutive seven days. Sleep parameter estimated by wrist actigraphy: sleep efficiency (SE), which is calculated by total sleep time divided by total time in bed, %

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of daytime sleepiness
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Paediatric Daytime Sleepiness Scale (PDSS) is an 8-item self-rated scale measuring daytime sleepiness, ranging in total scores from 0 to 32 with higher scores indicating more sleepiness.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of daytime fatigue
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Multidimensional Fatigue Inventory (MFI) is a 20-item self-rated scale on fatigue symptoms. There are three subscales, measuring the physical (possibly scored from 7 to 35), mental (possibly scored from 6 to 30), and spiritual (possibly scored from 7 to 35), dimensions of fatigue. A grand total score can be calculated by summing up the three sub scores. In all cases, a higher score represents higher fatigue symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of quality of life
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: KIDSCREEN-27 is a 27-item self-rated scale measuring health related quality of life measure for children and adolescents. There are five subscales on: physical well-being (possibly scored from 5 to 25), psychological well-being (possibly scored 7 to 35), autonomy & parents (possibly scored 7 to 35), peers & social support (possibly scored 4 to 20), and school environment (possibly scored 4 to 20). A grand total score can be calculated by summing up the five sub scores. In all cases, a higher score represents higher perceived well-being.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of suicidal ideation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Depressive Symptom Inventory Suicidality Subscale (DSI-SS) is a 4-item self-rated scale measuring suicidal ideation. Possible total scores range from 0 to 12, with higher scores indicating higher suicidal ideation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of subjective cognitive performance
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Cognitive Failures Questionnaire (CFQ) is a 20-item self-rated scale measuring perceived failures in daily cognitive tasks. Possible total scores range from 0 to 80, with higher scores indicating higher cognitive failures.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective cognitive performance (visual attention & task switching)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Trail Making Test for assessing visual attention and task switching. In Trail Making Test, longer reaction time indicates lower level of attention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective cognitive performance (inhibitory ability)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Go/No-go Task for assessing inhibitory ability. In Go/No-go Task, a higher error rate indicates lower inhibition control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective cognitive performance (working memory by digit span)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Digit Span Task for assessing working memory capacity. In Digit Span Task, a higher number of recalled digits indicates better working memory.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective cognitive performance (working memory by N-Back)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: N-back Task for assessing working memory capacity and manipulation. In N-back Task, a d prime score will be calculated based on the signal detection theory, where a higher score indicates better working memory performance.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective cognitive performance (episodic memory)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Chinese Auditory Verbal Learning Task for assessing episodic memory, where a higher number of recalled words indicates better episodic memory performance.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of objective cognitive performance (problem solving)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Wisconsin Card Sorting Test for assessing problem solving. In Wisconsin Card Sorting Test, lower executive functioning is indicated by a higher percentage of persistent errors and a higher number of trials taken to complete the first category.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep related attention bias
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Sleep-related Dot-Probe Task for assessing sleep-related attention bias. In the Sleep-related Dot-probe Task, a higher attention bias score indicates higher vigilance towards sleep-related stimuli.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of risk-taking & decision making
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Balloon Analogue Risk Task for assessing risk-taking and decision-making. In Balloon Analogue Risk Task, a score will be calculated by averaging the number of pumps on unexploded blue balloons, where a higher score indicates more risk-taking and impulsive propensities.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of dysfunctional beliefs and attitudes about sleep
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Dysfunctional Beliefs and Attitudes about Sleep (DBAS) is a 16-item self-rated scale measuring the respondent's sleep-related beliefs, more specifically, their expectations and attitudes regarding the causes, consequences, and potential treatments of sleep issues. A total score is calculated by averaging score of all items, possibly scored 0 to 10, with a higher score indicating more dysfunctional beliefs and attitudes about sleep.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of sleep hygiene and practice
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Sleep Hygiene Practice Scale (SHPS) is a 30-item self-rated scale measuring sleep hygiene behaviors, ranging in total scores from 30 to 180, with higher scores indicating lower levels of sleep hygiene.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of pre-sleep arousal
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Pre-Sleep Arousal Scale is a 16-item self-rated scale measuring pre-sleep arousal. There are two subscales on the cognitive and somatic manifestations of arousal, with eight items in each subscale (possibly scored from 8 to 40). In both cases, a higher score indicates higher pre-sleep arousal.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of overall severity of clinical symptoms
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, post-treatment (week 8/at the conclusion of last group session) for all participants; and additionally at post-treatment one-month and six-months for those in the two active treatment groups
secondary_outcome.description: Clinical Global Impression (CGI) Scale is a clinician-rated scale, comprised of two one-item subscales: Severity of Illness (CGI-S) subscale evaluating the severity of psychopathology, and Clinical Global Improvement Scale (CGI-I) evaluating change from the initiation of treatment. In both cases, the score is given on a seven-point scale, with higher values indicating higher severity of illness and larger improvement respectively.

intervention.description: The intervention will consist of 8 weekly group sessions (90-min, 5-8 adolescents in each group) of CBT-I delivered within a 10-week window. The treatment components in the CBT-I aim to address the behavioural, cognitive and physiological perpetuating factor of insomnia and include: psycho-education about sleep and sleep hygiene, stimulus control, sleep restriction, relaxation training, structured worry time, cognitive restructuring (targeting sleep-related dysfunctional cognitions), and relapse prevention.

The intervention will consist of 8 weekly group sessions (90-min, 5-8 adolescents in each group) of CBT-D delivered within a 10-week window. The main treatment elements of CBT-D include: psycho-education about depression, self-monitoring, behavioural activation, improving social skills, communication skills and problem solving skills, cognitive restructuring (addressing negative and irrational thoughts often associated with depression in adolescents), relaxation techniques, and relapse prevention.

facility.name: Sleep Research Clinic & Laboratory, Department of Psychology, The University of Hong Kong
